name: FortiManager
description: This app performs firewall configuration and security policy management actions in FortiManager

actions.description: Validate the asset configuration for connectivity using supplied configuration

actions.verbose: This action can be used to create a firewall policy within FortiManager. When specifying a firewall policy name, make sure that it is unique. FortiManager requires every firewall policy to have a distinct name, or else the action will fail.

level.description: Level type at which to create the firewall policy. Choosing 'ADOM' (Administrative Domain Name) of the FortiManager server allows you to perform against that particular ADOM

package.description: The Policy Package name or full folder path to create the firewall policy within

source_interface.description: Incoming (ingress) interface to specify for the firewall policy. Interfaces must already exist in the FortiManager server. If specifying more than one, enter as a comma-separated list

destination_interface.description: Outgoing (egress) interface to specify for the firewall policy. Interfaces must already exist in the FortiManager server. If specifying more than one, enter as a comma-separated list

source_address.description: Source IPv4 Addresses, address objects, and/or address group names to specify for the firewall policy. If providing new address objects that are NOT of type Subnet (IPv4/Netmask format) or any new address groups that do not already exist in the FortiManager server, the action will fail. If specifying more than one, enter as a comma-separated list

destination_address.description: Destination IPv4 Addresses, address objects, and/or address group names to specify for the firewall policy. If providing new address objects that are NOT of type Subnet (IPv4/Netmask format) or any new address groups that do not already exist in the FortiManager server, the action will fail. If specifying more than one, enter as a comma-separated list

action.description: Policy action to specify for the firewall policy. Accept: Allows sessions that match the firewall policy. Deny: Blocks sessions that match the firewall policy. IPSec: Firewall policy becomes a policy-based IPsec VPN policy

status.description: 'Enable' or 'Disable' this firewall policy on your FortiManager instance

schedule.description: Name for the schedule to be associated with the firewall policy (e.g. always, none)

service.description: Service and Service group names to create for the firewall policy. If specifying more than one, enter as a comma-separated list

log_traffic.description: Enables or disables logging of either all sessions or only security profile sessions

actions.verbose: This action can be used to retrieve one specific firewall policy or multiple firewall policies. To filter for a specific firewall policy, provide the policy's name and if you would like to display all policies within a package, simply leave the policy name parameter blank.

level.description: Level type at which to list the firewall policies

adom.description: ADOM name. Only required for 'ADOM' Firewall Policies

package_path.description: The full folder path nested within the policy package

policy_name.description: Specific firewall policy name whose details you want to retrieve

actions.verbose: This action can be used to update an existing firewall policy. Whichever parameters you wish to change, make sure to provide all the values since this action will overwrite all the values. If you leave a parameter blank, it will not be changed.

level.description: Level type at which to update the firewall policy. Choosing 'ADOM' (Administrative Domain Name) of the FortiManager server allows you to perform against that particular ADOM

package.description: The Policy Package name or full folder path to update the firewall policy within

name.description: The policy name that will be updated. Note: this does not update the policy name itself

source_interface.description: Incoming (ingress) interface to add to the firewall policy. Interfaces must already exist in the FortiManager server. If specifying more than one, enter as a comma-separated list

destination_interface.description: Outgoing (egress) interface to specify for the firewall policy. Interfaces must already exist in the FortiManager server. If specifying more than one, enter as a comma-separated list

source_address.description: Source IPv4 Addresses, address objects, and/or address group names to specify for the firewall policy. If specifying more than one, enter as a comma-separated list

destination_address.description: Destination IPv4 Addresses, address objects, and/or address group names to specify for the firewall policy. If specifying more than one, enter as a comma-separated list

action.description: Policy action to specify for the firewall policy. Accept: Allows sessions that match the firewall policy. Deny: Blocks sessions that match the firewall policy. IPSec: Firewall policy becomes a policy-based IPsec VPN policy

status.description: 'Enable' or 'Disable' this firewall policy on your FortiManager instance

schedule.description: Name for the schedule to be associated with the firewall policy (e.g. always, none)

service.description: Service and Service group names to create for the firewall policy. If specifying more than one, enter as a comma-separated list

log_traffic.description: Enables or disables logging of either all sessions or only security profile sessions

actions.verbose: This action can be used to create an address object of either subnet or FQDN type. When specifying an address name, make sure that it is unique. FortiManager requires every address object to have a distinct name, or else the action will fail.

ip_netmask.description: IP address or IP address and netmask. Examples of valid formats: 1.1.1.1, 1.1.1.1/32, 1.1.1.1/255.255.255.255

policy_group_name.description: Name of policy group to be added to address

address_name.description: Name of address object to delete

actions.verbose:
This action can be used to retrieve one specific address object or multiple address objects.

The filter_by parameter in the list addresses action can take multiple filtering criteria. For example, to filter by multiple address types you can use the following: `[["type", "==", "subnet"],["type", "==", "fqdn"]]`. Note that when using multiple criteria, only one needs to be true in order for the address object to be returned in the results. Therefore, using the previous example, the action will return address objects of both type subnet and FQDN.

When running the list addresses action adhoc, you can directly type in something like `[["type", "==", "subnet"],["type", "==", "fqdn"]]` into the filter_by parameter. However, if you are incorporating this action into a Classic Playbook, you must directly edit the action's code block in the playbook code editor and enclose the value in quotes, formatting the value like so: `"[["type", "==", "subnet"]]"`. This issue does not persist for Modern Playbooks.

address_name.description: Name of address object to retrieve. If none is specified, this action will return all matching values.

filter_by.description: Criteria to filter results by. Use the following format to specify filter: [["{attribute}", "==", "{value}"]]

limit.description: Maximum number of addresses to return. Default is 0, which returns all results.

offset.description: The starting point of the results to be returned.

actions.verbose: This action can be used to update an existing firewall address object. Note that you can only update the IP/Netmask value if the address is of type Subnet. Similarly, you can only update the FQDN value if the address is of type FQDN. This action does not currently support changing the address type of an address object.

address_name.description: Name of address object to update

ip_netmask.description: Updated IP address and netmask (e.g. 0.0.0.0/32) to assign address object

fqdn.description: Updated Fully Qualified Domain Name to assign address object

policy_group_name.description: Name of policy group to be added to address

actions.verbose: This action can be used to block IPV4 addresses. By specifying either a single IP address or multiple addresses as a comma-separated list, this action will create address objects if they don't already exist. The address objects will then be added to the specified address group. If the address group does not exist, the action will fail.

level.description: Level type at which to block IP addresses

adom.description: ADOM name. Only required for 'ADOM' blocking of IP addresses

package_path.description: The full folder path nested within the policy package

policy_name.description: Specific firewall policy name for blocking IP addresses

address_group_name.description: Specific address group name for for blocking IP addresses

ip_addresses.description: Comma-separated list of IP addresses to block

example_values: Total ips blocked: 0, Total ips already blocked: 1, Total created address objects: 0, Total address object already exists: 0, Total address object failed: 0

actions.verbose: This action can be used to unblock IPV4 addresses. By specifying either a single IP address or multiple addresses as a comma-separated list, this action will remove any address objects from the specified address group but will NOT delete the address objects from FortiManager. If the address group does not exist, the action will fail.

level.description: Level type at which to unblock IP addresses

adom.description: ADOM name. Only required for 'ADOM' unblocking of IP addresses

package_path.description: The full folder path nested within the policy package

policy_name.description: Specific firewall policy name for unblocking IP addresses

address_group_name.description: Specific address group name for for unblocking IP addresses

ip_addresses.description: Comma-separated list of IP addresses to unblock

example_values: Total ips unblocked: 2, Total ips already unblocked: 0

actions.verbose: This action can be used to delete a firewall policy within FortiManager. You must provide the policy ID of the firewall policy you wish to delete. This policy ID can be retrieved from the list firewall policies action.

level.description: Level type at which to create the firewall policy. Choosing 'ADOM' (Administrative Domain Name) of the FortiManager server allows you to perform against that particular ADOM

package.description: The Policy Package name or full folder path of the firewall policy to delete

policy_id.description: Policy ID (can be retrieved from 'List Firewall Policies' action) to delete

example_values: Status: Successfully deleted firewall policy ID: 29

actions.verbose: This action can be used to block a URL. A URL of type 'simple' will exactly match a URL, while a 'wildcard' or 'regex' URL can be configured to match different permutations. The URL will be added to the specified web filter profile if it exists, otherwise the action will fail.

level.description: Level type at which to block URLs. Choosing 'ADOM' (Administrative Domain Name) of the FortiManager server allows you to perform against that particular ADOM

web_filter_profile_name.description: The Web Filter profile name to use to block URLs

type.description: Type of URL format. Wildcard must include a '*'

example_values: URL already exists in URL filter list

actions.verbose: This action can be used to unblock a URL. If the URL exists in the web filter profile, it will be removed. If the specified web filter profile does not exist, the action will fail.

level.description: Level type at which to unblock URLs. Choosing 'ADOM' (Administrative Domain Name) of the FortiManager server allows you to perform against that particular ADOM

web_filter_profile_name.description: The Web Filter profile name to use to unblock URLs

example_values: URL does not exist in URL filter list

actions.verbose:
This action can be used to create a new address group. When specifying an address group name, make sure that it is unique. FortiManager requires every address group to have a distinct name, or else the action will fail.

The `members` parameter accepts names of existing address objects and address groups, IP/netmask addresses, and FQDN addresses in a comma-separated list. If the IP/netmask or FQDN address does not exist on FortiManager, this action will automatically create an address object with the respective address value and add it to the address group.

level.description: Level type at which to create the address group. Choosing 'ADOM' (Administrative Domain Name) of the FortiManager server allows you to perform the action against that particular ADOM

address_group_name.description: Unique name of address group you want to create

members.description: Comma-separated list of address objects or address groups to add to the address group. Accepted values include FortiManager address object names, IP/netmask, and FQDN

actions.verbose: This action deletes an existing address group. Make sure the address group name entered is valid and exists on your FortiManager asset. If an invalid address group name is used, the action will fail.

level.description: Level type at which to create the address group. Choosing 'ADOM' (Administrative Domain Name) of the FortiManager server allows you to perform the action against that particular ADOM

address_group_name.description: Unique name of address group you want to create
